member.name: T:Remotion.ObjectBinding.IBusinessObject
member.summary: The interface provides functionality to get and set the state of a business object.

remarks.para: An knows its through the property.
Its state can be accessed through a number of get and set methods as well as indexers.
remarks.note: Unless you must extend an existing class with the business object functionality, you can use the class as a base implementation.

member.name: T:Remotion.ObjectBinding.IBusinessObjectProperty
member.summary: The IBusinessObjectProperty interface provides functionality common to all business object property spezializations for the individual data types.
member.remarks: A business object property only implementing the generic IBusinessObjectProperty should only be used if the data type of the value accessed through this property is unknown. This rule is espacially important when using business object binding, since the controls used to access the values require a strong typed business object property.

member.name: T:Remotion.ObjectBinding.IBusinessObjectProvider
member.summary: Provides functionality for business object providers.
member.remarks:
A business object provider is able to retrieve services (e.g. the ) from the object model, as well as provide functionality required by more than one of the business object components (Class, Property, and Object).
If this interface is implemented using singletons, the singleton must be thread save.
You can use the default implemtation () as a base for implementing the business object provider for your object model.

member.param: The type of to get from the object model. Must not be .
member.returns: An instance if the type or if the sevice could not be found or instantiated.

remarks.note: If your object model does not support services, this method may always return null.

member.name: T:Remotion.ObjectBinding.IBusinessObjectReferenceProperty
member.summary: The IBusinessObjectReferenceProperty interface is used for accessing references to other instances.

member.name: M:Remotion.ObjectBinding.IBusinessObjectReferenceProperty.SearchAvailableObjects(Remotion.ObjectBinding.IBusinessObject,Remotion.ObjectBinding.ISearchAvailableObjectsArguments)
member.summary: Searches the object model for the instances that can be assigned to this property.
member.param: The business object for which to search for the possible objects to be referenced.
A parameter-object containing additional information for executing the search. Can be .
member.returns: A list of the instances available. Must not return .
member.exception: Thrown if evaluated but this method has been called anyways.
member.remarks:
This method is used if the seach statement is entered via the Visual Studio .NET designer, for instance in the control.
If your object model cannot evaluate a search string, but allows search through a less generic method, provide an overload, and document that getting the list of available objects is only possible during runtime.

member.name: M:Remotion.ObjectBinding.IBusinessObjectReferenceProperty.Create(Remotion.ObjectBinding.IBusinessObject)
member.summary: If is , this method can be used to create a new business object.
member.param: The business object containing the reference property whose value will be assigned the newly created object.
member.exception: Thrown if this method is called although evaluated .
member.remarks: A use case for the Create method is the instantiation of an business object without a unique identifier, usually an Aggregate. The aggregate reference can be until one of its values is set in the user interface.
